results.title: Doctor Who: the seeds of doom
results.brief_description: The Doctor from 172 episodes, Tom Baker, stars in this story by Robert Banks Stewart. Two mysterious pods are discovered by a research team digging in the Antarctic. They know that the pods are over twenty thousand years old, but nothing beyond that. The pods are no mystery to the Doctor, who identifies them as Krynoid, a hostile and alien plant species. The Doctor isn’t the only one interested in the pods, an insane millionaire, Harrison Chase (Tony Beckley) is eager to get his hands on them, his motives unclear. They cannot contain the pods to the Antarctic and a pod reaches England, setting forth a ferocious carnivore. It’s up to the Doctor and Sarah (Elisabeth Sladen) to once again save mankind. Also starring John Challis and Mark Jones.

results.title: Doctor Who: the monster of Peladon
results.brief_description: The Doctor (Jon Pertwee) and Sarah arrive at the medieval planet Peladon, half a century after the Time Lord’s first visit. The planet is apparently secure under the benign rule of the Galactic Federation, with the resident Pels enjoying their existence. There is trouble ahead however, as the Federation is at war with Galaxy Five and Peladon takes on a political importance because of its natural resource of the rare mineral, trisilicate. The miner Pels react violently to the warring, believeing mining machinery has woken the spirit of the legendary Aggedor. The Federation counter attacks the inward fighting by sending in a military taskforce led by Commander Azaxyr and his ice warriors. The Doctor and Sarah must act as peace-keepers and discover a few interesting things along the way regarding the evil spirit and corruption amongst the Federation. Also starring Elisabeth Sladen, Donald Gee, Nina Thomas and Rex Robinson.

results.title: Doctor Who: the hand of fear
results.brief_description: The Doctor (Tom Baker) and his companion Sarah Jane Smith (Elisabeth Sladen) find themselves in an English quarry when a freak accident traps Sarah beneath tons of rock. Miraculously, she survives, and is found clutching a large stone hand which seems to have assumed power over Sarah who has become possessed. She disappears and the Doctor follows her to a nearby atomic power station. It’s up to him to discover the source of the hand’s power and to determine why Sarah has found her way to the nuclear reactor. The Doctor’s search takes him across the galaxy to a long-dead world.

results.title: Doctor Who: the green death
results.brief_description: The suspicious death of a miner at the inactive local pit owned by the mysterious Global Chemicals brings UNIT and the Doctor to sleepy Llanfairfach, Wales. Could the waste products from their revolutionary new oil refining process be at fault? For there, deep down in the mines, thousands of giant maggots lay gestating - a dangerously unknown terror waiting to be unleashed upon the world. But by whom? Just who is the power behind Global Chemicals? And who or what is the boss? The Doctor, Jo and the Brigadier must move quickly to find the answers, for the death toll is already rising and the gestation period of the maggots is coming to an end.

results.title: Doctor Who: the curse of fatal death
results.brief_description: The Doctor invites the Master to the planet Terserus, whose inhabitants communicated using controlled flatulence, and were wiped out when they discovered fire. The Doctor announces that he is retiring and going to marry his companion, Emma. The Master attacks the Doctor with a series of traps, which he had the architect build into the structure by travelling back in time to bribe him. The Doctor counters these traps by travelling in time and bribing the architect first. The duel ends with the Master falling down a shaft into the sewers. It takes the Master 300 years to escape after which he travels back in time to the moment he left, bringing the Daleks with him, they capture the Doctor and Emma, and the Master explains that he has gotten the Daleks assistance by promising them a Zektronic Energy Beam, with which they will conquer the universe. The Daleks attempt to kill the Master after he gives them the Beam, the Daleks death ray damages the Beam, starting a chain reaction that will destroy them all. Only the Doctor can stop it, but he was hurt in the explosion and regenerates. Trying to repair the Beam he causes two more regenerations and finally succeeds, only to be struck down by a feedback pulse from the beam, and dies. The Master and the Deleks renounce the evil ways in honour of the Doctor, but against all odds the Doctor manages to regenerate again, only this time, much to Emma’s dismay and the Master’s delight, he regenerates into a woman. Points of Interest : Shown as part of the 1999 Comic Relief Telethon. Joanna Lumley was frequently put forward as a possible candidate for the new Doctor whenever it was suggested he should become a woman, an idea popular in the 1980’s. Script written by Stephen Moffat.

results.title: Doctor Who: the ark in space
results.creator_credit: BBC, Philip Hinchcliffe and Rodney Bennett
results.brief_description: The Doctor (Tom Baker), Sarah Jane Smith (Elisabeth Sladen) and Harry (Ian Marter) find themselves on space station Nerva - otherwise known as the Ark - where mission control appears to be sabotaged and all life forms have been cryogenically preserved in suspended animation. Sarah Jane finds herself one of the frozen chosen when she lies on a tranquilliser couch/short-range matter transmitter. When two of the Ark’s inhabitants are re-animated, med-tech Vira (Wendy Williams) and leader Noah (Kenton Moore) - they reveal that civilisation underwent mass cryogenic processing to avoid their imminent destruction by solar flares; the only problem being that their best laid plans for a programmed re-animation didn’t work due to their equipment being damaged by an unknown being. The unknown beings turn out to be The Wirrn, an insect race who have found a valuable food source on the Ark and laid it’s eggs on the solar stacks. It’s up to the Doctor to save the day. This was the second episode in which the fourth Doctor (Tom Baker 1974-1980) appeared. Originally broadcast in the UK on BBC1 between January 25 and April 15, 1975. Written by Robert Holmes.

results.title: Doctor Who: revenge of the Cybermen
results.brief_description: The Doctor (Tom Baker), with Sarah and Harry in tow arrive at Space Station Nerva, which has been overcome by a deadly plague. Few remain on the station, and the Doctor suspects the Cybermen are somehow connected. Nearby the station is planet Voga, where there are expensive gold mines. Gold is a deadly metal to the Cybermen so their ultimate plan is one of destruction. However the waring factions on Voga are at civil unrest. Who will have the upper hand? Will the Doctor ouththink the Cybermen? And who will survive? Starring Tom Baker (Doctor Who), Elisabeth Sladen (Sarah Jane Smith) and Ian Marten (Harry Sullivan).

results.title: Doctor Who: remembrance of the Daleks
results.creator_credit: British Broadcasting Corporation, John Nathan-Turner and Andrew Morgan
results.brief_description: The Doctor and Ace (Sophie Aldred) land in London, 1963, amidst an environment of mysterious magnetic fluctuation and a military stake out. Leaping in the back of scientific advisor Professor Rachel Jenson’s wagon, the time lord and his companion find themselves in the thick of a siege in which men are being killed by a mysterious “death ray”. The Doctor informs Group Captain Gilmore, the man in charge, that these are the energy weapons of the Daleks. The Daleks have come to retrieve something the first Doctor left behind at the school of his grand daughter Susan, the powerful Hand of Omega. The Daleks are species divided however, with two warring factions competing for the Hand. On one side there is Dalek Emperor Davros, on the other the renegade Imperial Dalek faction headed by the Supreme Dalek. The Doctor must stop the Daleks from gaining the Hand and protect Group Captain Gilmore and his men from extinction. Boasting more special Dalek induced effects than in previous episodes, Sylvester McCoy starred as the seventh Doctor in this 25th season of the cult series for a period of three years (1987-1989). Written by Ben Aaronovitch.

results.title: Doctor Who: death to the Daleks
results.brief_description: In this exciting adventure the Doctor (Jon Pertwee) is forced into a desperate race against time… An inexplicable power loss strands the tardis on the sinister planet Exxilon where the Doctor meets an expedition from Earth seeking a rare mineral that can cure the virulent space plague that threatens all human life. Nearby Sarah (Elisabeth Sladen) discovers a mysterious Citadel but is captured by the savage Exxilons who prepare for her sacrifice. The Doctor must uncover the secrets of the ancient city, locate the source of the power drain, save Sarah and help the Earth expedition. But his plans are threatened by new arrivals on the planet - the Doctor’s oldest and deadliest enemies - the Daleks.

results.title: Doctor Who: city of death
results.brief_description: A peaceful holiday in Paris takes a macabre turn for the Doctor and Romama (Tom Baker, Lala Ward) as cracks start to appear in the fabric of time itself. Uncovering a plot by the sinister Count (Julian Glover), to steal the Mona Lisa, the Doctor goes on a dangerous quest which takes him four hundred million years into the past. These four cleverly written episodes are by David Agnew, a.k.a. Douglas Adams of ‘Hitchhikers guide to the Galaxy’ fame, and includes cameo appearances by John Cleese and Elanor Bron. Douglas Adams would later re-work this story into his novel: ‘Dirk Gently’s Holistic Detective Agency’.
